He looked at her one last time, her greasy purple smile a final, pathetic taunt, and then he tossed her onto the top of the pyre. He went back into the garage, which now felt vast and empty, and returned with a can of turpentine and a box of matches. He doused the pile of canvases, the solvent’s sharp scent a clean, acrid smell of purification. He struck a match, the tiny flame a stark contrast to the grey sky, and dropped it onto the canvases. The turpentine ignited with a soft *woosh*, and the fire began its work. The heat was intense, and the smell of burning oil paint and canvas was thick and acrid. He watched as the faces contorted in the flames, the sneers melting, the hateful eyes blistering and turning to black ash. He was not destroying art; he was burning evidence. He was giving the Goblin a funeral.

When the fire had burned itself out, leaving behind only a blackened, smoking patch on the ground and a lingering, foul smell in the air, he went back inside. There was one last piece of business. He sat down at the clunky desktop, the cracked laptop screen a dark, broken mirror. He opened it, and the machine whirred to life. He navigated past the scar on the screen to his blog. Wotan’s-Eye’s comment was still there, a siren call from a world he no longer inhabited. He ignored it. He navigated to the blog’s administration panel, a place he knew as intimately as his own palette. He found the button he was looking for. It was small, tucked away at the bottom of a menu, its label written in a bland, corporate font. *Delete this site permanently.* He clicked it. A box appeared, asking for confirmation. *Are you sure you want to permanently delete ‘The Goblin’s Grimoire’? This action cannot be undone.* He stared at the words. *Cannot be undone.* It was the most beautiful sentence he had ever read. He typed the name of the blog into the confirmation field, his fingers steady, and then he clicked the final button. The page refreshed, displaying a simple, sterile message: *Your site has been successfully deleted.*

Christopher leaned back in his chair, the sound of the computer’s fan the only noise in the quiet room. It was done. The paintings were ash. The blog was a ghost in the machine, its digital spores neutralized. The Goblin was gone. He stood up and walked back to the garage. The room was transformed. It was no longer a grotto or a cathedral, but a simple, empty workspace. And in the center of it all, on the solitary easel, stood the portrait of Alistair Perrett. It was the only thing left. It was the first page of a book that had not yet been written. He looked at the compassionate, witnessing eyes of the man on the canvas, and for the first time since he was a boy, he felt no anger, no shame, and no fear. He felt only the vast, silent, terrifying, and exhilarating emptiness of a clean slate.

The exhilarating emptiness of the clean slate lasted for approximately six hours. It was the length of Christopher’s first deep, dreamless sleep in a decade, a bottomless black pit of exhaustion. He awoke to the second phase: the terrifying emptiness. The silence of the bungalow was no longer a sign of freedom, but a profound and suffocating vacuum. The grand, symbolic gestures of the previous day—the fire, the digital suicide—had been acts of destruction. They had cleared the ground, but now he stood in the center of the cleared lot with no tools, no materials, and no blueprint for what to build next. The absence of the Goblin’s constant, agitating monologue was a new kind of madness. It was like living next to a noisy factory your entire life and then waking up one morning to find it gone, the silence so absolute it rang in your ears, making you aware of the frantic, unsupported beating of your own heart.

He spent the morning as a ghost in his own life, drifting from room to room. Every surface seemed to accuse him of his long neglect. A faint, acrid smell of smoke still clung to the air, a reminder of the funeral pyre in the backyard. The most potent ghost, however, was in the garage. He opened the door and stood on the threshold, unwilling to enter. The portrait of Alistair Perrett sat on the easel, a sentinel in the cavernous, empty space. It was the only object in the room that did not feel like a part of his old, diseased life. But it was not a comforting presence. Its compassionate gaze had been a balm when he was in the throes of creation, but now, in the quiet aftermath, it felt like a standard. It was a testament to the man he had been for three weeks, a man he had no idea how to continue being without the structure of the sittings, without the quiet, demanding presence of the subject. The portrait was a quiet, constant question: *What now?*

Half a world away, Alistair Perrett stepped out of the climate-controlled passage of the aircraft and into the gleaming, hyper-ordered reality of Incheon International Airport. The air was cool and clean, smelling faintly of floor polish and recycled air. Digital screens glowed with crisp, multilingual characters, displaying flight times with razor-sharp precision. The contrast with the worn, sagging reality of western Pennsylvania was so jarring it felt like a form of temporal whiplash. He had been in a place where the past was a raw, open wound; he had returned to a place where the future was a meticulously managed project. As he joined the silent, orderly queue for immigration, he found himself looking at the faces around him—the tired businessman, the young backpacker, the grandmother greeting her family—not as demographic data points, but with a painter’s eye. He saw the subtle play of light on a cheekbone, the intricate map of wrinkles around an eye, the specific, unique geometry of a mouth. He wondered about their stories, the invisible histories that shaped their expressions. The scholar who analyzed symbols had been infected by the artist who painted souls.

His apartment, when he finally returned to it, felt like a museum exhibit of his former life. The minimalist furniture, the carefully curated books, the vast, clean window looking out onto the glittering, abstract tapestry of Seoul—it all felt strangely sterile, lacking the dense, complicated, and foul reality of the garage. It was a space designed for thinking, and he had just returned from a place that demanded feeling. His research assistant, Ji-hoon, met him there that afternoon to debrief, bringing with him a folder of academic journals and a flask of the barley tea Alistair preferred. The young man was as bright and sharp as ever, his mind a finely tuned instrument of theory and citation. He was eager to hear about the trip, to learn about the new material for the paper on reactionary iconography. “How was the fieldwork, sunsaengnim? Did you find your goblin?” Ji-hoon asked, his tone light and full of intellectual curiosity.

Alistair looked at his bright, earnest student and felt a profound sense of incommensurability. It was like trying to describe the color red to a person born blind. “The trip was… transformative,” Alistair said, the word wholly inadequate. “I have decided to abandon the paper.” Ji-hoon’s jaw dropped slightly. “Abandon it? But your thesis was brilliant. The framework was perfect.” Alistair walked to the window, his back to the student. “The framework was the problem,” he said quietly. “It was a cage. And the subject was not what I thought it was.” Ji-hoon, ever observant, noticed a faint, dark smear on the cuff of the professor’s travel trousers, a smudge of something that looked like ash. He had never seen his mentor look anything but immaculate. The trip had changed him, but in a way that defied academic notation. Alistair simply stared out at the perfect city, his mind filled with the image of a scarred and beautiful painting, a work of art no one but its creator would likely ever see, and he knew it was the most important paper he would ever be a part of.

Back in Pennsylvania, the hollow ache in Christopher’s chest had finally been given a name: hunger. And with it, a more terrifying realization: he had almost no money. His life as the Goblin had been one of ascetic monasticism, his needs minimal, his income a sporadic trickle from the occasional sale of a grotesque painting to a fellow traveler in the digital darkness. That income was now gone. The abstract problem of *What now?* had resolved itself into the brutal, concrete reality of needing to buy groceries. He needed a job. The word itself was a humiliation, a surrender to the very system of wage slavery and mediocrity he had spent a decade despising. The Goblin’s ghost screamed in protest, but its voice was weak, drowned out by the rumbling of his empty stomach.

He went to the local library, a place he associated with the dull, passive consumption of approved narratives. He sat at a public computer, surrounded by the quiet rustling of ordinary people living their ordinary lives, and he felt a profound and painful sense of alienation. He was an immigrant in his own hometown. He typed “jobs” into the search bar. The screen filled with a litany of his own private hells: retail associate, fast food crew member, delivery driver. Each listing was a small death. His pride, the last vestige of the Goblin’s armor, buckled and cracked. He was about to close the browser, to retreat back to his empty house and starve rather than submit to this indignity, when his eyes caught a listing under the ‘skilled trades’ section. The word ‘Painter’ jumped out at him. His heart gave a painful lurch. He clicked on it. It was not for an artist. It was for a small, local contracting company. “Painter/Finisher needed for residential and commercial work. Must be reliable, detail-oriented, and experienced with surface preparation and application of latex and oil-based paints. Own transportation a plus.” It was a trade. It was manual labor. It was honest work. It was the most humbling and terrifying opportunity he could possibly imagine. With a hand that trembled, not with rage, but with a strange, nascent hope, he clicked the button to print the application form. He stood by the humming library printer and waited for the page to emerge, a simple sheet of paper asking for his name, his address, his history. It was a blank slate, and for the first time, the emptiness did not feel like a void, but like a beginning.
